reviewText: Between the direction of David Lean and the photography of Freddie Young, this is a fabulous visual treat, one to be treasured.  I'll certainly be interested to see what this looks like when someone makes a Blu-Ray version of this film.Unfortunately, the story as well as the great visuals, seem to dissipate in the last hour-plus of the movie. It just kind of peters out, like Lawrence's desert campaign.The acting, led by Peter O'Toole in the title role, is superb with the possible exception of Anthony Quinn, who overacts. Two of the all-time greats - Alec Guiness and Omar Sharif - also added life to this monumental epic story. This was O'Toole's first role, too, and probably his most famous and some think his best.as the premier actor in the business.For a film this long and with such little action, it's amazing it entertains as well as it does. For those who need some pretty women to aid in the story, forget it: in fact, there are NO women that I can remember. It gets by with the cinematography, O'Toole intense acting portraying a real-life vain, courageous, stubborn and obsessed Englishman trying to unite the Arabs to fight the Turks.Another very memorable and impressive aspect of this movie was the soundtrack. Is it my imagination or were soundtracks (like this one) more important and remembered better than movies in the last quarter of a decade? The main theme song is played throughout the film and I still remember it 47 years later.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a great film and one of my very favorite movies.  I love everything about it.  The exquisite length and pacing of this film can only work when the dialogue, acting, and pictures support it.  Here the movie is packed with everything wonderful from the first sound of the tympani to the credits.My father always felt that Peter O'Toole was cheated when the best actor Oscar went to Gregory Peck for "To Kill a Mocking Bird" and I have always agreed with that view.  Nothing against Mr. Peck, but O'Toole gave a spectacular performance that has not lost its power over time.While I am not a film scholar, I have always found David Lean a compelling story teller with his images as well as the dialogue.  Here, the images are so beautiful, powerful, and vast that they never leave the memory.  They become part of our visual language.  Who doesn't get thirsty when the Nefud is being crossed?  Whose heart is touched when Lawrence comes out of the Sinai into the officers club with the boy?  Who doesn't feel a mix of blood lust and revulsion in the battle scenes - especially at the train and the slaughter of the Turks on the way to Damascus?The extras on the making of the movie and the reprint of the original theatrical program (though in a much smaller size) are quite good and valuable.  It is hard for me to get my kids to understand that we used to get dressed up to go to movies and they did sell program which people bought, read, and KEPT.  Different times ...Yes, the events in which Lawrence played a part were a sideshow of a sideshow of the Great War, but they certainly get their monument in this great film.
summary: This great film retains its visual and dramatic power
Title: N/A

reviewText: To some, Lawrence of Arabia is the greatest film ever made. I'm in that camp. Seeing this restored version, scanned at 4K resolution, is a wonderful experience. The image is flawless, the music soars, the desert so intimidating, the huge battle scenes of hundreds of Arabs on camel or horseback breathtaking. The huge sweep of this film is something you will never see in a contemporary film. The story of the brilliant T E Lawrence will captivate you. A must see.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I agree with other reviewers here. The reviews should not be lumped together since they are different versions. The information on this version omits run time. There is no way to guess which version this is without a run time. So NO SALE until Amazon gets its act together and seperates the various versions or publicizes the whole truth about what is contained in each version. Really shameful of them.Having said that, the people who find this movie boring are missing several points, that might make Lawrence of Arabia the greatest hollywood movie of all time. Its still completely timely.1) The roots of the conflict between America and the Muslims are accurately revealed in this movie. Britain converted its navy from coal to oil just before the war started. Of course all the western powers immediately followed the lead of the British. The oil in the middle east became very valuable over night. So the west had a vested interest in conquering and colonizing the area. Oil became strategic.2) Lawrence is NOT A HERO. HE'S A LOSER. He's used and manipulated by the British and then when he's no longer useful he's sent home. Lawrence wants a great adventure and he wants to unify and free the Arabs. In the end the adventure is far more than he bargained for. He ends up responsible for the deaths of his guide, his young charges and he's forced to execute the man he saves in the desert. (His pistol is used to kill 3 of them, metaphorically it represents his naiveté.) His fame goes to his head and he begins to believe his own legend, virtually discarding his friends, when his real accomplishments, other than Aqaba, don't amount to much. He participates in mass murder against surrendering Turks. He fails to unify the Arabs. His diplomatic and managerial skills are inadequate. He only realizes that he's failed and has been used and manipulated at the very end when he's unceremoniously, and shamefully thanked then shipped back to Britain.Lean said the only morally decent person in the movie was Anthony Quayle's character, Col. Harry Brighton, who also realizes, in disgust at the end, he too has been used to help them use Lawrence.That Lawrence appears to be a winner but is actually a loser is Lean's and more importantly producer Sam Spiegel's greatest triumph. He fools the audience into thinking war is a great adventure but if you watch closely enough, you see that its an ugly horrible thing that devalues and destroys the humanity in almost all it touches.In fact although Lean was a great director it was really Sam Spiegel's movie. He tried for years to have it made, and finally succeeded. This is a movie about manipulation, deceit, politics and culture at its deepest level and the best scenes are when Lawrence deals with the powers of each culture. When they use his considerable ego to manipulate him. Both the British and the Arabs use him to their own ends.
summary: Which version? Why won't you tell us?
Title: N/A

reviewText: David Lean's masterpiece. There has never been another movie more beautifully filmed or edited. The director took great chances with this film. There isn't a woman in the cast. Much of the action is on the desert. It is quite talkative. It is long. But with all this said, it still dazzles the eye and mind. The Blu-ray edition is an excellent package. Forget the criticisms that the filmmakers fiddled with history and that Peter O'Toole isn't physically suited to play the role. He is excellent, and the supporting cast, several of whom were Lean favorites over the course of his career (Alec Guinness, Jack Hawkins, Omar Sharif) show how the best actors can assume different roles without making the viewer feel he has seen the same character too many times. This is an absolute MUST for motion picture fans. And thanks to Blu-ray, it is now preserved for generations to come in a format that does it justice.

reviewText: I have the blu-ray (restored) version. I've never seen this movie before but I'm glad I finally did a few days ago. Yes, its long but it's also measured and paced very well to allow the story to unfold in a much more natural way than most modern movies. It allows you to more fully understand the character and his motives/choices etc. The blu-ray video quality is exceptional especially considering the age of the source material. I can't give it five stars however for picture quality because there are spots that have either damage or some other (albeit minor) flaw that takes just a tiny bit away from the film over all. To spite the few flaws I saw this film looks fantastic, really. In some spots it looks like a much more recent movie, it's that good. The sound, well the sound was good but not great as you can expect based on the soundtrack's age. If you're a film buff and haven't seen this movie, borrow it or buy it. Either way you will be treated to quite an adventure. Enjoy.
summary: Now that's a movie! Almost perfect...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Blu-Ray Video: Easily 5 out of 5. The cinematography on display in this film is arguably the finest you will ever see in a major motion picture. The visuals blew me away. I had the privilege, and I do mean privilege of seeing this on a 160" projected image in glorious HD thanks to a friend that recently purchased the new BenQ W1070 HD Video projector from Amazon for only $999. Cinephiles should take notice. This projector is a must have for film lovers if you have the space for a large screen.Audio: 3  out of 5. In the restoration process, I'm sure this was the best they could do. My frustration with the films audio had to do with how out of balance the volume level of the score was with the dialog on screen. I would have to turn down the music it was so loud and then turn it back up again to hear clearly what people were saying. Other than that it was an impressive mix for a 50 year old film.The Film: 2 out of 5. Let me explain. I have grown up with a love for film watching classics like It's a Wonderful Life, The Great Escape, The Bridge on the River Kwai, The Ten Commandments, and more modern classics like Dances with Wolves, and the Shawshank Redemption to name but a few. While I can enjoy a check your brain at the door film; I really appreciate great storytelling more than anything else. Special effects and explosion never make up for poor writing. This was the biggest and most critically acclaimed Hollywood classic that I had never watched. I had avoided it on home video and TV largely due to the fact that I knew from reading about the film that it deserved to be seen in a large screen format. Period! Not a 30" TV or even a more modern 60" big screen HDTV. It was shot on Super 70mm for a very large IMAX like format to be viewed on. Having recently purchased my own HD video projector I jumped at the chance to pick this up on Blu from Amazon for only $9.99. My screen at home is 92" which is great, but still doesn't begin to do this film justice. So when I had the chance to finally view my copy on my friends' 160" screen I jumped at the opportunity!The performances in this film are excellent. The cast is truly stellar with some of the most recognizable names of that era on display. I really enjoyed David Leans' "Bridge on the River Kwai." However, I have never watched a more loved and critically acclaimed film that left me more disappointed than this one did. If I could use one word to describe "Lawrence of Arabia" it's this. BLOATED. Never has a critically acclaimed award winning film been in greater need of an editor with some authority than this one. I felt sorry for my wife and her friend that I talked into watching this film with me. I can appreciate a deliberately slow film that is building up to something when the pay off is worth it. In this case it wasn't. This film should have been 2 1/2hrs to 3 hours at the most. 4 hours was nothing more than self indulgence by a director that had enough clout to get away with it. I have wanted to watch Doctor Zhivago for some time, but I am very leery of it at this point after what I just went through with "Lawrence of Arabia." I probably still will, but I'm in no hurry at this point. The film was so slow that when exciting things did happen; they didn't really excite me or the people I was viewing it with. While I don't regret having watched it; I am deeply disappointed and have no plans to ever give 4 hours of my life to it again. Had I not been watching it on a massive screen; I would have been fast forwarding through parts of it due to boredom. I know I won't change anyone's mind about the film that already loves it, but I needed to vent after giving it four hours of my life that I will never get back. I appreciate the history of the story and think it's clearly a story that should be told on film, but it left me utterly cold.
summary: A Word of Caution to First Time Viewers of This Film

reviewText: The movie is great, and in general, so is the Blu=Ray; however:1. There are two scenes when the audio is not in sync with the picture. Seems like if they worked this long on creating the Blu-ray, there would not be scenes with the audio out of sync.2. Ultraviolet is terrible. To even try to download the movie, I had to upgrade programs on my computer, create a Sony account that gave them a lot of personal information and then I had to circumvent the standard security on my Mac to allow the movie to download. However, even at that, the Sony download manager repeatedly failed. After nine hours, I still do not have a playable version on my computer.In general, Ultraviolet stinks. I'd rather pay less for a movie and not have a digital copy than use Ultraviolet. First, some movies only stream. What good does that do me on an airplane at 30,000 feet? And why would I want to stream a movie when I own a Blu-Ray copy? I'm done with Ultraviolet. I may buy a movie that has it as an option, but only because I want the movie. I'm not wasting another minute of my life trying to set up an Ultraviolet movie for playing on a portable device.

reviewText: First time I saw this film was the year it was released in 1962 ~ believe it was a wonderful motion picture ~ now that I see it again on DVD ~ know now how wrong I was  ~ this is a GREAT film.  But the real stars is the landscape (desert) shifting and whispering as it does and the score by Maurice Jarre.  Jarre's score is simply epic in sound, overwhelming in depth and has completely captured the time and place with every note and measure.Even though Peter O'Toole (T.E. Lawrence) is the main character ~ it is Alec Guinness (Prince Feisal) and Anthony Quinn (Auda abu Tayi) whose performances give you the essence of the story and make it work, let's not forget Omar Sharif (Sherif Ali ibn el Kharish) when we first see him at the well, an impacting scene between him and O'Toole.David Lean (director) did such a fantastic job, won the oscar for that year for Best Director ~ Maurice Jarre won for Best Score and Freddie Young for Best Cinematography ~ but once again was the landscape and score we remember so well!If you enjoyed this DVD ~ check out the score on CD ~ "Lawrence Of Arabia" (Silva America SSD-1010) The Philharmonia Orchestra conducted by Tony Bremner ~ digitally recorded with additional music.Total Time: 227 minutes...Columbia/Tri Star...(2001)

reviewText: The film is breathtaking and the performances are brilliant.  David Lean ("Bride on the River Kwai", "Dr. Zhivago") directs from a script by Robert Bolt ("A Man for All Seasons")  As with any historical film, one can quibble with the accuracy of this or that, but T.E. Lawrence was already being mythologized in his own lifetime, so any portrayal is bound to be controversial. Lowell Thomas's reporting and lecture tour made Lawrence and international celebrity while he was still in the field fighting the Turks, and his own autobiographical writings both added to the legend and deepened the mystery, of this contradictory, brilliant and maddening figure.The Blu Ray disc looks and sounds gorgeous and the extras are very nice.  The only thing I could wish for that is not here is a commentary from Lean himself, but that was not to be.

reviewText: Easily one of the best films ever made, LOA is now also one of the best blu-rays. A frighteningly clean transfer makes this look like it was made yesterday---except no one makes movies this sprawlingly epic any more (except in CGI, which is another animal altogether).Two discs for nine clams is a gift, truly. Endless extras, most of them well made, show how many people are devotees of this masterpiece. Spielberg's bit is quite nice. The wonderful score sounds gorgeous in surround. But it's how good the film looks that is the real highlight here.I never even bothered to see this on dvd, as it demands a large screen. But I couldn't resist giving the blu-ray a gander on a large LCD screen, and am thrilled I did. While the massive shots will never really be done justice on a non-theater screen, they nonetheless look fabulous here. The blue skies are among the purest I've ever seen on a home screen, and the endless vistas still look literally awesome. It still astonishes that this was O'Toole's screen debut, and his performance is as magnificent as ever. Sharif and Quinn et al match him step for step; few films have this many stellar turns.But this is after all Lean's film, and a case could be made that no film has ever been directed more flawlessly. Just look at all the extras in some of those scenes; how did he make it all work? Still seems near impossible. Over 3.5 hours, it demands patience and thought, two things most filmgoers tend to want to avoid. But if you put in the time and open your mind along with your eyes, you will walk away changed by Lawrence Of Arabia. The superb script is brought to life by Lean's amazing framing and composition skills, and he sure know how to draw the best from his actors. The interviews show that everyone knew how good this was going to be from day one, and the actors sure loved Lean.As they should. Few of them ever matched their heights here again. If you've never seen this, I still say you should wait and see it on a big screen first. No flat screen can ever match a real 70 mm print, and being swallowed by the desert is part of LOA's majesty. But if you've got no art house cinema playing oldies in your town, then by all means grab this blu-ray. It's one of the best yet made, and it sure is nice to be able to lay on the sofa drinking a cold brew as Lawrence and his camels plod across the endless deserts. The almost total lack of grain in the picture is astonishing; the only grain left are the trillions of grains of sand, and you can almost pick them out single in some shots. They may have reworked this in remastering.processing, but it was done with taste and precision. This is one of the best BD restorations to date that I've seen.This film deserved this level of transfer, and thanks to those who made it happen. What a treat to be able to watch this at leisure any time you desire, in cinema quality. They don't make 'em like this any more, and never will.

reviewText: David Lean's magical ability to put grandeur on the screen is unmatched. He stands alone as the Maestro of the Sweeping Epic and Lawrence Of Arabia may be his greatest work. The film astonishes the eye. Lean's cinematography is brilliant and, at times, approaches dreamlike status. Lean has the knack of telling, with a single, wordless long shot, a story that would otherwise fill 1,000 pages of prose. In Lawrence of Arabia, the endless desert serves as the main character. All else is secondary which may be why Peter O'Toole's over there top performance wears a bit thin after 3 hours plus. HIs acting in this, his major film debut is, to say the least, emotive. Nonetheless he is compelling in his blue eyed portrayal of T.E. Lawrence.  Truth told, I was a little relieved to be rid of him by the film's end. That said Lawrence of Arabia stands alone in the world of cinematic achievement and can fairly be called a film Masterpiece.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I bought the Blu-Ray restored version because I wanted to see what a really great movie, recorded on film, not digitally, would look and sound like on my new high-end Panasonic Plasma TV (P50GT50 - INCREDIBLE! and bought from Amazon!), Yamaha RX-V775 AV Receiver, and speakers looked and sounded like. The picture is glorious. The cinematography is perfect. The brilliance of the desert is amazing. But, when I heard it, I panicked because the audio is distorted. Since this was the very first blu-ray (or any DVD) I had played on my new setup, I thought it was my setup, but after checking it out on Amazon streaming, Netflix, TV, and a few other DVD's, I realized (thankfully) that this particular edition of Lawrence of Arabia is gorgeous to view and painful to hear.The sound isn't the worst I've heard, but it is distorted enough that it is noticeable and grating. I'd buy a different version or wait for the next release in the hope they fix the sound.

reviewText: Spectacular to look at a great story and Peter O'Toole the perfect choice to play T.E Lawrence. David Lean is obviously the benchmark for many directors and one thing that strikes me is the judicial use of music, sound effects and silence. So many directors now think that it's necessary to have sound effects for every action on screen or mood music for every emotion mainly I think to cover up the paucity of their scripts and story! So watching this movie is very enjoyable. Highly recommended.

reviewText: David Lean's classic film is restored to perfection in the Blu ray release of Lawrence of Arabia. Here, the colors are sharp and vibrant when called for, and the muted shades of the desert are so detailed you can almost feel the desert heat and the shifting of the sands. A new life for a film made in 1962. Audio hasn't been neglected, with a 5.1 DTS HD Master soundtrack that envelops you with the genius of Maurice Jarre's timeless score. In addition to the film, there are worthwhile extras and exclusive to the Blu ray edition, a remembrance of Lawrence of Arabia by Peter O'Toole. This is the best way to enjoy one of the best films ever made in a home environment!
summary: Lawrence of Arabia Restored Blu ray -  a masterpiece brought back to perfection!
Title: N/A

reviewText: How fortunate to be able to see to this editor's cut (221-minute) version of this 70-mm film in DVD format. With all due respect to the superior acting provided by all members of the cast, the desert remains the central character because of the exquisite care with which director David Lean presents it. How insignificant human activities seem when set within the context of the endless, timeless sand. Nonetheless, occasionally an exceptional leader emerges who -- for whatever reasons -- eventually acquires mythic stature. Such a leader was T.E. Lawrence, author of The Seven Pillars of Wisdom on which Robert Bolt's screenplay is based. Paradoxically, we know a great deal about his relatively brief life and career and yet in so many ways he remains an enigma. Like a force of nature, perhaps he can never be fully understood. This film traces his military career from Cairo in 1917 until just before his death in 1935 at age 47. Most of the film focuses on his efforts to help the Arabs to achieve their independence, leading their revolt against the Turks and then trying (without much success) to get the leaders to trust and cooperate with each other. (Given the circumstances in the Middle East today, this is an especially interesting subject which Lean examines in some depth.) The cast includes a number of distinguished actors such as Omar Sharif (Sherif Ali ben El Kharish), Alex Guinness (King Feisal), Anthony Quinn (Auda Abu Tayi), Jack Hawkins (General Allenby), Claude Rains (Dryden) and Jose Ferrer (Turkish Bey). However, O'Toole's commanding presence dominates each scene in which he appears just as Lawrence's force of will overcomes Arab doubts about his leadership.For me, this film has lost none of its impact since I first saw it in 1962. Yes, it is an epic in so many ways but Lean wisely includes a number of intimate moments which remind us that these are human beings whom his cast members portray. To both the British and to the Arabs, Lawrence was an enigma...and so he is to me. I am reminded of Whitman's observations in Song of Myself: "Do I contradict myself? Very well, then, I contradict myself. I am large. I contain multitudes." The same can be said of O'Toole's Lawrence. Even by the conclusion of this almost three-hour film, we still do not fully understand the motives which drive Lawrence's behavior nor the demons which probably help to explain his immensely complicated personality. He seems to me to be -- like the vast dessert across which he establishes his celebrity -- a force of nature which is what it is, in some respects beyond our comprehension.
summary: A Great Film...and So Much More

reviewText: I was an usher (part-time) while going to Ryerson in Toronto. I got to see parts of this film over and over..in 70MM. Reserved seating. I brought my girlfriend for a matinee.Everything about this film is as close to perfection as any film can be. For a first time viewer, I would suggest doing a little research about LOA...history..geography and you will enjoy this film even more. I have the DVD and I am considering getting the Blu-Ray for the added quality and extras. As I write $10.

reviewText: This is the most famous and most rewatched film of the early 1960s.  If you have not seen this film, it is because you do not want to.  This edition of the film is magnificent.  The picture and sound reproduction are excellant.  The many extras are(mostly) very good.  If you have seen this film you certainly love it.  You will not find a better DVD edition of this movie than this one.

reviewText: PICTURE QUALITY:  STUNNING.  The color is vivid the details are clear.  Even simple interior shots.  The steely determination, frustration and eventually world weariness in Peter O'Toole's deep blue eyes are what make this entire movie.  In this restored version you can his eyes as windows to the soul in laser-like focus.  There's one very minor scene where Omar Sharif's character is chided for trying to learn English from a children's book.  The small book is briefly shown on part of the screen in another actor's hands.  You can read all of the text quite easily on both pages.THE STORY:  It's long and it starts slow.  It's not made for folks that want immediate "run from the explosion" type action but when something happens it has more depth and human gravitas.  The first time through (years ago) I couldn't get past the halfway mark.  Now I find myself kind of fascinated by this story:  this guy who for awhile "goes native", who has all these crazy dreams and for awhile accomplishes the impossible.Lawrence is basically portrayed as a tactical and leadership genius and dreamer who is blind to the realities of serving two masters.  You see it everyday in the news and in human relationships - people are in denial of the deals they are cutting, promises made with themselves or others.There's a funny scene early in the movie when Lawrence is called into the office of the bigwig general and, upon marching in and presenting himself, Lawrence passive-aggressively salutes the general in a nervous, foppish manner.  (I presume because he doesn't respect pompous authority not earned by merit).  The general calls him on it and says something like:  "I can't tell if you're an idiot or if you have no manners!".  Lawrence backpedals, tries to smooth things: "Yes Sir, I have the same problem!"  and explains it as awkwardness and personal mannerisms.  The general then tells him to "Shut Up!"  Lawrence goes "Yes Sir" with this crap eating grin and faux obsequiousness.  The contradictions between what's going on inside and outside of him in that scene are hilarious.There are many good scenes in this movie.My advice:  Watch it over two nights.Cheers!ADDENDUM:  Techno garbage you can skip:  I have a Sony BDP-790 BR player, LG 60" 1080p Plasma, Pioneer VSX-1021 receiver, Def Tech center, Panasonic everything else speakers & sub.
Title: N/A
